title: How many Beatles songs were completed in one take? Which ones? - Quora

response.answer_text: ***REVISED*** - April 12, 2020 In their recording career, The Beatles completed FOUR songs in one take and none of them was “Twist and Shout.” I am forced to revise this answer because I errored. My source for the recording information is Mark Lewisohn’s book entitled “The Complete Beatles Recording Sessions.” Lewisohn is one of the leading authorities on Beatles recordings. He has a stellar rep. My problem was that I didn’t read his book more carefully the first time around. I have re-read the book and now I think I have the information correct. I am indebted to David McKay and Mitchell Martin for pointing out my mistakes. The Beatles recorded FOUR songs in one take. Interestingly enough, there was one song sung by each Beatle. They are as follows: On Monday, Feb. 11, 1963, Ringo took lead vocals for the first time in the studio on the Shirelles’ “Boys,” written by Luther Dixon and Wes Farrell. Ringo played the drums and sang and the song was recorded in one take. That was the day the Beatles recorded 10 songs in a marathon session for the first album “Please Please Me,” which was released on March 22, 1963.On Sunday, March 1, 1964, Paul did his greatest ever Little Richard impression on Little Richard’s “Long Tall Sally.” George Martin joined the four Beatles on piano and the five did a near-perfect rendition of “Long Tall Sally.” They didn’t bother with a second take. The song appeared on a 4-song EP released June 1, 1964, that included “Matchbox,” “I Call Your Name” and “Slow Down.”On Sunday, Oct. 18, 1964, the Beatles had a very productive recording session of songs for their 4th album in 21 months, “Beatles For Sale.” At one point they completed three songs in 5 takes. George sang the lead on a cover version of the Carl Perkins song “Everybody’s Trying To Be My Baby.” There was an incredible amount of echo on George’s voice, but the take was well done and another take wasn’t taken.The next song that day was John singing Chuck Berry’s “Rock and Roll Music.” The four Beatles were joined by George Martin playing the piano. Martin did a fine job, complete with several Glissandi (slides on the keys). The group did one take, it was crisp and clean. No other takes were made. “Rock and Roll Music” and “Everybody’s Trying to Be My Baby” both appeared on “Beatles For Sale,” released on Dec. 4, 1964.What are some of the lessons that can be gleaned from these facts? First, all the songs done in one take were songs they had played in their Hamburg days. They were used to playing them “live.” Granted, Ringo had not been in Hamburg, but Pete Best had sung “Boys” with the Beatles in Hamburg and Ringo had actually sung “Boys” with his previous band. Second, all the one-take songs were in the Rock and Roll or Rockabilly vein. Those kind of songs sound more exciting and authentic if they’re a little raw and unpolished, so why do a lot of takes? Third, all the one-take songs were cover songs. Had they been Lennon and McCartney songs, I think they may have done a number of takes. Songwriters want to present their own songs in the best light possible. The more polish the better. During that marathon session of Feb. 11, 1963, the Beatles did 12 takes of “I Saw Her Standing There,” 8 of “Do You Want to Know a Secret,” 17 of “There’s a Place,” and 16 of “Misery.” In the sessions for their second album, “With the Beatles,” which were on July 18, July 30, and Sept. 11–12, 1963, they took 23 takes of “It Won’t Be Long,”, 13 of “All My Loving,” 15 of “All I’ve Got To Do,” 9 of “Not A Second Time,” 16 of “Hold Me Tight,” 19 of “Don’t Bother Me,”18 of “Little Child,” and “7 of “I Wanna Be Your Man.” The point of relating all this is that from the beginning, the Beatles worked very diligently in the studio. Early in their career, they may have tried to be efficient in the studio. But after “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” I don’t think that they cared at all how much time they spent in the studio. It wasn’t unusual for them to do 30 or more takes of songs. For example, on the White Album, McCartney got Lennon and Harrison to sit for 67 straight takes of “I Will.” Now, “I Will” is a lovely little tune, but 67 takes? But then, Lennon took 112 takes of “Sexy Sadie” and Harrison did 67 takes of “Long Long Long.” The Beatles became less efficient and more time-consuming in their recording efforts later in their career. Ultimately, it’s a myth that the Beatles routinely recorded songs in one take. It happened FOUR times in their entire career.

The early ones. But can I just say, it does not matter? The Rolling Stones, famously, throw up a few room mics, muck about a bit, playing together as a band, and the engineer presses record when he thinks they are about there. And that is a *brilliant* technique, which delivered some all-time classic tracks. But the Beatles were different (after the first couple of albums). They realised, rightly, that the recording studio is an additional instrument. That if you mess about with it enough, you can produce new and interesting sounds. That you can do multiple takes of your own voices singing different harmonies, that no live take can replicate. This is why they stopped touring (combined with the lack of adequate live sound equipment, which meant nobody could hear them). So they became possibly the definitive “studio band” instead, at least until others like Pink Floyd, 10cc and Queen came along. It is a different way of working. But to deny the role of “the studio” as an additional band member is very short-sighted. I am a proud owner of “Recording the Beatles” and also, even more rarely, a copy of a 1960s history of EMI given to me by Albert Lee during a session. Recording the Beatles : The Studio Equipment and Techniques Used to Create Their Classic Albums by Kevin Ryan & Brian Kehew (2006) Hardcover: Amazon.co.uk: Brian; Ryan, Kevin (The Beatles) Kehew: Books
